Explanations about Options.-e(M):
use netstat(8)-format for displaying the routing table. -ee will generate a very
 long line with all parameters from the routing table.
Explanations about Options.-n(M):
show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host names. This
 is useful if you are trying to determine why the route to your nameserver has
 vanished.

Answers.MP Summary: show / manipulate the IP routing table
Top-3 Scripts:
su_762608: ip route add <NET1> dev <DEV1> src <SRC1> table <NAME1>
  ip route add <NET2> dev <DEV2> src <SRC2> table <NAME2>

ip route add default via <IP1> table <NAME1>
 ip route add default via <IP2> table <NAME2>

ip route add 192.168.57.0/24 via 192.168.162.5 
  iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o tun0 -j MASQUERADE

ip route add 192.168.112.0/24 via 192.168.162.9
  iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o tun0 -j MASQUERADE

ul_391364: # add new routing table 100 and set its default routing to your default gw
ip route add table 100 default via $DEFAULT_GW

# add rule to use the new table for packets marked 10
ip rule add fwmark 10 table 100

# flush routing cache
ip route flush cache

Explanations about Options.-l(M):
Listen for an incoming connection rather than initiating a connection to a remote
 host. The destination and port to listen on can be specified either as non-optional
 arguments, or with options -s and -p respectively. Cannot be used together with -x
 or -z. Additionally, any timeouts specified with the -w option are ignored.

Answers.MP Summary: arbitrary TCP and UDP connections and listens
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Listen on a specified port and print any data received
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_20497190: Allow incoming traffic to CentOS server

Explanations about Options.-A(C): The command "netstat -l -n -A inet" will list all Internet ports that are currently open on your server.
Explanations about Options.-A(M):
Specifies the address families (perhaps better described as low level protocols) for which
 connections are to be shown. family is a comma (',') separated list of address family
 keywords like inet, inet6, unix, ipx, ax25, netrom, econet, ddp, and bluetooth. This has
 the same effect as using the --inet|-4, --inet6|-6, --unix|-x, --ipx, --ax25, --netrom,
 --ddp, and --bluetooth options.
Explanations about Options.-l(M): Show only listening sockets. (These are omitted by default.)
Explanations about Options.-n(M): Show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host, port or user names.

Answers.MP Summary: Print  network  connections,  routing tables, interface statistics, masquerade connections, and multicast memberships
